text.p: While a colder winter favoured Swedish power utility Sydkraft during the fourth quarter of 1996, 1997 has started somewhat warmer than expected, Sydkraft's chief executive Goran Ahlstrom said on Monday.
"So far it has been slightly warmer than we expected it to be," Ahlstrom told Reuters in an interview.
Ahlstrom said snow levels in the Northern region of Sweden were notably higher this year compared to the same time last year.
How much spring flood will add to water reservoirs is however difficult to predict as a quick change of weather can make the snow evaporate or melt too quickly.
Ahlstrom believes reservoir levels in 1997 will exceed last year's. "I'm counting on it being better this year," Ahlstrom said. He did not think the spot price of electricity would drop further.
Sydkraft made a profit after financial items of 2.50 billion crowns in 1996, slightly up on the previous year. Electricity sales to the consumer market rose by about five percent.

Notably colder weather and an increase in market share accounted for the rise in sales. Ahlstrom said the weather accounted for 2.5 percent of the rise whilst the increase in market share explained the other 2.5 percent.
Sydkraft will present a forecast for 1997 when the company releases its annual report April 28.
